newsitem.title: CHINA: China's top Catholic church official dies at 80.
newsitem.headline: China's top Catholic church official dies at 80.

text.p: Bishop Joseph Zong Huaide, the most senior member of China's state-backed Catholic church, has died in Beijing at the age of 80, officials said on Saturday.

Bishop Zong died of a heart attack in a Beijing hospital, said an official of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, an advisory body of which Zong had been a standing committee member.

Zong was chairman of the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association, a Beijing-sponsored organisation that is responsible for China's Catholics but maintains no links with the Vatican. He was also chairman of the Chinese Catholic Bishops' College.
An official of the association said the funeral would take place after a national holiday to mark the return of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty on July 1.
Zong was born in eastern Shandong province in 1917, graduated from a Catholic seminary in the provincial capital Jinan and became a priest in a local village in 1943.

He was imprisoned for several years during the ultra-leftist 1966-76 Cultural Revolution when all China's churches were closed and the faithful persecuted, but he re-emerged in 1980 to take up a position in the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.
In an interview last year, Zong said China's Catholic churches were prepared for normalisation of ties with the Vatican.
However, he said the Vatican's diplomatic recognition of Beijing's island rival Taiwan and a requirement that Rome should not interfere in China' domestic affairs continued to divide the two sides.
Official figures say China has some four million Catholics, although church organisations and Western academics estimate the number as closer to 8-10 million.
The underground church, loyal to Rome, is believed to be even larger.
